dataset.title: Zooplankton Data for North Inlet Estuary, South Carolina, from 1981 to 1992, North Inlet LTER

abstract.para: This data package consists of Zooplankton Data for North Inlet Estuary, South Carolina, from 1981 to 1992, North Inlet LTER. The purpose of the long term monitoring of zooplankton was to characterize the fauna in the water column larger than or equal to 153 microns and to obtain some basic information on each of the taxa encountered there. A sampling regime of collections made at regular biweekly intervals was implemented to provide the best quantitative assessment of long term changes in the zooplankton population dynamics.

section.title: LTER Network Data Access Requirements
section.para:
The access to all LTER data is subject to requirements set forth by this policy document to enable data providers to track usage, evaluate its impact in the community, and confirm users' acceptance of the terms of acceptable use. These requirements are standardized across the LTER Network to provide contractual exchange of data between Site Data Providers, Network Data Providers, and Data Users that can be encoded into electronic form and exchanged between computers. This will allow direct access to data via a common portal once these requirements have been fulfilled. The following information may be required directly or by proxy prior to the transference of any data object:
Registration
Name
Affiliation
Email address
Full Contact Info
Acceptance of the General Public Use Agreement or Restricted Data Use Agreement, as applicable
A Statement of Intended Use that is compliant with the above agreements. Such statements may be made submitted explicitly or made implicitly via the data access portal interface.

section.title: Conditions of Data Use
section.para:
The re-use of scientific data has the potential to greatly increase communication, collaboration and synthesis within and among disciplines, and thus is fostered, supported and encouraged. Permission to use this dataset is granted to the Data User free of charge subject to the following terms:
Acceptable Use. Use of the dataset will be restricted to academic, research, educational, government, recreational, or other not-for-profit professional purposes. The Data User is permitted to produce and distribute derived works from this dataset provided that they are released under the same license terms as those accompanying this Data Set. Any other uses for the Data Set or its derived products will require explicit permission from the dataset owner.
Redistribution. The data are provided for use by the Data User. The metadata and this license must accompany all copies made and be available to all users of this Data Set. The Data User will not redistribute the original Data Set beyond this collaboration sphere.
Citation. It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set. Citation should take the following general form: Creator, Year of Data Publication, Title of Dataset, Publisher, Dataset identifier.
Acknowledgement. The Data User should acknowledge any institutional support or specific funding awards referenced in the metadata accompanying this dataset in any publications where the Data Set contributed significantly to its content. Acknowledgements should identify the supporting party, the party that received the support, and any identifying information such as grant numbers.
Notification. The Data User will notify the Data Set Contact when any derivative work or publication based on or derived from the Data Set is distributed. The Data User will provide the data contact with two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the Data Set and will provide copies, or on-line access to, any derived digital products. Notification will include an explanation of how the Data Set was used to produce the derived work.
Collaboration. The Data Set has been released in the spirit of open scientific collaboration. Data Users are thus strongly encouraged to consider consultation, collaboration and/or co-authorship with the Data Set Creator.
By accepting this Data Set, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. The Data Owner shall have the right to terminate this agreement immediately by written notice upon the Data User's breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. The Data User may be held responsible for any misuse that is caused or encouraged by the Data User's failure to abide by the terms of this agreement.

section.title: Disclaimer
section.para: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation contained in this Data Set, complete accuracy of data and metadata cannot be guaranteed. All data and metadata are made available "as is". The Data User holds all parties involved in the production or distribution of the Data Set harmless for damages resulting from its use or interpretation.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: North Inlet encompasses about 2,630 hectares of tidal marshes and wetlands near Georgetown, South Carolina, USA. North Inlet-Winyah Bay features high quality, ocean-dominated waters and salt marshes in North Inlet, contrasting with the brackish waters and marshes of Winyah Bay. The bay estuary is dominated by riverine discharges from a watershed impacted by agricultural, municipal and industrial development. Former rice fields and canals provide another system for study within the Reserve.The North Inlet LTER site is located on the eastern shore of the Atlantic Ocean, in a small tidal estuary near Georgetown, South Carolina, U.S.A. Coordinates for the North Inlet estuary are latitude 79 degrees 10 minutes and longitude 33 degrees 11 minutes. Zooplankton collections were made at two locations in Town Creek, the major tidal creek in the North Inlet estuary. The DD site is located near the inlet mouth 10 m off the southern shore of Town Creek at a small drainage very near the former site of the Town Creek platform. The boat was anchored, bow into the ebbing tidal current, and the paired weighted zooplankton nets lowered to the bottom. Tows were taken shortly after mid-ebb (2-hours prior to low tide) when tidal velocities were swiftest, often exceeding 0.5 m/sec-1. Water depth averaged 4 m. The BB site is located approximately 2 km inshore from the inlet in Town Creek 5 m off the mouth of Boze's Creek. Tows, taken at mid-ebb, were fished at tidal velocities less than or equal to 0.5 m/sec-1. Water depth averaged 4 m. The BB collection site is located in Town Creek 5 m off the mouth of Boze's Creek. Town Creek is the main tidal creek in the North Inlet estuary and is bounded by extensive Spartina alterniflora marshes. The creek banks are covered by large clusters of the American oyster (Crassostrea virginica), shell rubble, and intermittent muddy flats. The BB zooplankton station average water depth at mid ebb is approximately 4 m. Tidal velocity averages 0.3 m/sec-1. Water clarity varies with water temperature and to some extent wind direction, velocity, duration, and rainfall. The creek bottom at this site is muddy clay covered by varying accumulations of detrital plant and fecal matter. The DD collection site is characterized by a high energy, sandy or heavily scoured bottom habitat. Mid ebb water velocities can exceed 1.0 m/sec-1, re-suspending large amounts of sand and debris. Water clarity varies with water temperature and to some extent wind direction, velocity, duration, and rainfall. At both sites, Town Creek is a well-mixed, high salinity creek inundated by diurnal tides. Rain input, primarily runoff, depresses salinities briefly depending on the duration and frequency. Water temperatures mirror local air conditions; semi--temperate/tropical (see temp. and sal. on file for details).

section.title: Entry verification
section.para: Multiple levels of entry verification were performed. Data were initially checked for entry errors by Beth Thomas and Jan Blakely, who originally entered the data on the full-screen management entry programs. Once all data entry errors were corrected, hard copies of the data on the system were sent to Lynn Barker (the Research Specialist who counted the samples) to proof against the original raw data sheets. All data on the system from samples 1-275 (through December 1992) have been certified error-free by Lynn Barker.

section.title: Date of last update while at North Inlet LTER
section.para: December 31, 1992

section.title: Last modification at LTER Network Office
section.para: Individual data files (LTER.NIN.ZPK.1981.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1982.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1983.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1984.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1985.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1986.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1987.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1988.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1989.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1990.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1991.txt, LTER.NIN.ZPK.1992.txt) were concatenated into a single file spanning the dates from 1981 to 1992. Original fixed column format was changed to comma separated value format. These changes occured in March 2012

dataset.pubPlace: Long Term Ecological Research Network Office

dataTable.entityDescription: ZooPlankton Data for North Inlet Estuary, South Carolina, from 1981 to 1992, North Inlet LTER

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: North Inlet encompasses about 2,630 hectares of tidal marshes and wetlands near Georgetown, South Carolina, USA. North Inlet-Winyah Bay features high quality, ocean-dominated waters and salt marshes in North Inlet, contrasting with the brackish waters and marshes of Winyah Bay. The bay estuary is dominated by riverine discharges from a watershed impacted by agricultural, municipal and industrial development. Former rice fields and canals provide another system for study within the Reserve.The North Inlet LTER site is located on the eastern shore of the Atlantic Ocean, in a small tidal estuary near Georgetown, South Carolina, U.S.A. Coordinates for the North Inlet estuary are latitude 79 degrees 10 minutes and longitude 33 degrees 11 minutes. Zooplankton collections were made at two locations in Town Creek, the major tidal creek in the North Inlet estuary. The DD site is located near the inlet mouth 10 m off the southern shore of Town Creek at a small drainage very near the former site of the Town Creek platform. The boat was anchored, bow into the ebbing tidal current, and the paired weighted zooplankton nets lowered to the bottom. Tows were taken shortly after mid-ebb (2-hours prior to low tide) when tidal velocities were swiftest, often exceeding 0.5 m/sec-1. Water depth averaged 4 m. The BB site is located approximately 2 km inshore from the inlet in Town Creek 5 m off the mouth of Boze's Creek. Tows, taken at mid-ebb, were fished at tidal velocities less than or equal to 0.5 m/sec-1. Water depth averaged 4 m. The BB collection site is located in Town Creek 5 m off the mouth of Boze's Creek. Town Creek is the main tidal creek in the North Inlet estuary and is bounded by extensive Spartina alterniflora marshes. The creek banks are covered by large clusters of the American oyster (Crassostrea virginica), shell rubble, and intermittent muddy flats. The BB zooplankton station average water depth at mid ebb is approximately 4 m. Tidal velocity averages 0.3 m/sec-1. Water clarity varies with water temperature and to some extent wind direction, velocity, duration, and rainfall. The creek bottom at this site is muddy clay covered by varying accumulations of detrital plant and fecal matter. The DD collection site is characterized by a high energy, sandy or heavily scoured bottom habitat. Mid ebb water velocities can exceed 1.0 m/sec-1, re-suspending large amounts of sand and debris. Water clarity varies with water temperature and to some extent wind direction, velocity, duration, and rainfall. At both sites, Town Creek is a well-mixed, high salinity creek inundated by diurnal tides. Rain input, primarily runoff, depresses salinities briefly depending on the duration and frequency. Water temperatures mirror local air conditions; semi--temperate/tropical (see temp. and sal. on file for details).

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: Because previous field studies indicated that stage of tide and time of day affected organism abundance at the zooplankton stations, it was necessary to sample about every 14 days, keeping these variables "constant". Thus paired, simultaneous zooplankton tows were made, fishing the mid ebb tidal current, at the same sites, when the end of the ebbing tide occurred near noon. Replicated biweekly measurements were used to identify seasonal patterns of abundance for each taxon. Comparisons of abundance between years provided information on long term trends. Collection at a sandy, turbulent inlet and a major marsh creek location allowed for a comparison of two habitat types.

section.title: Field Protocols
section.para: Paired simultaneous zooplankton collections were made at each of two LTER sampling sites (BB, DD) in Town Creek every two weeks. Samples were taken 2-3 hours prior to a midday low tide. From Cruises 1 - 9 ( 1/20/81 - 5/15/81 ). Two plankton nets were towed from the stern of a small outboard boat simultaneously. The nets were deployed by two persons who released the nets from the moving boat while keeping tension on the tow ropes. Weights attached to the bridle chuck allowed the net to settle near the bottom before the forward motion of the boat moved the net forward. From that point the tow was 90 seconds in duration increasing boat speed at 30 second intervals, allowing an oblique pattern from bottom to surface. Due to continual difficulty with this method, beginning with cruise 10 ( 6/1/81 ), an alternate method of zooplankton collection was implemented. On station, a small outboard boat was anchored (bow into the ebb current) and two weighted closed 30 cm diameter plankton nets were lowered to the creek bottom via a metered nylon rope, and a messenger released to open the nets for fishing. An oblique collection of the water column was made, sampling the bottom, mid, and surface levels for prescribed time intervals (never more than 2 minutes at each level). The amount of water filtered was registered by a torpedo-shaped General Oceanics flow meter Model 2040 mounted in the mouth of each net. Readings were taken before and after each tow. To insure an optimal amount of water filtered (~4 cubic meters) a minimum of ~2000 flow meter revolutions was required before sample retrieval. In the event this minimum was not obtained, the nets were lowered back into the water and an adequate amount of water was filtered. Upon sample retrieval, the contents of the net were concentrated into a windowed cod end jar, poured into a 1 liter pre-labeled Nalgene jar, and preserved with 30 ml of 100% formalin, buffered and stained with Rose Bengal. Sample replicates were returned to the lab for analysis.

section.title: Gear Description
section.para: Each zooplankton net had a 30 cm diameter mouth and a 102 cm cylindrical body followed by a 74 cm conical section which tapered to a 10 cm cod end mouth. The mesh size of the entire net was 153 micron Nytex. A bridle attached the 30 cm diameter stainless steel round mouth frame to a tow rope. The cod end was a PVC cylinder with a Nytex (153 micron) window. A General Oceanics flow meter Model 2040 was mounted just inside the net mouth, slightly off-center.

The zooplankton collection apparatus consists of a 153 micron mesh Nytex plankton net (described above) mounted to an opening assembly. The opening apparatus consists of a series of three 45 cm long, 1" diameter, hollow, stainless steel bars. Installed near the ends of each bar were copper sleeves mounted perpendicular to the pipe length. Braided nylon line (1/4") ran through the sleeves and the apparatus was assembled such that the upper and lower bars were fixed with the middle bar sliding up and down along the nylon line. The net was mounted to the upper and middle bars allowing the net mouth to be closed, prior to deployment. A trip mechanism on the tow line was triggered by a messenger and the net opened. Each net was weighted with a 1/4 m long, 10 lb. stainless steel weight. At greatest depths, the net fished 1/2 m from the creek bottom. This distance prevented the nets from filling with large amounts of sand and fecal material.

section.title: Lab Analysis
section.para: Prior to counting, the entire sample was sieved, rinsed in fresh water and the formalin disposed of. The sample was then rinsed into a graduated beaker and volume brought to 200 ml. A 2 ml stempel pipet sub-sample was removed and placed in a gridded counting tray. All organisms greater than or equal to 153 micron were identified to appropriate taxon and/or life stage and enumerated using a Wild binocular microscope at 24X. Beginning with Cruise 81 ( 4/12/84 ), samples were counted using a Leitz Diavert inverted microscope at 16X. Adult copepods were identified to species and non-adult copepods to species/genus and developmental stage (naupliar or copepodid). Adult and developmental stages of other plankters were identified to phylum, class, or family (see zooplankton data sheet on file). Data were recorded as numbers/sub-sample to be later converted to numbers/cubic meter. Upon computation of the 2 ml sub-sample count, the entire sample was sieved through 1.0 mm mesh, rinsed and the "larger" organisms identified and enumerated. The sample was recombined, stored in a labeled .25 l flint jar, preserved in a buffered 10% formalin solution stained with Rose Bengal. Samples were stored by cruise/date and station.

section.title: Counts
section.para: Raw counts of the 2ml sub-sample and the 1.0 mm sieved portion were recorded for all organisms encountered. Total numbers in the entire sample were calculated using Equation 1. The volume of water filtered was calculated with Equation 2. Concentrations of the taxa were then calculated using Equation 3. Data sheets were stored by cruise/date awaiting computer entry. Data were entered as concentrations (density; #/m3) based on the 2 ml sub-sample.
Equation 1: Raw Count Na = 2 ml sub-sample count of organism a
MF = Multiplication factor
Na X MF = Ta (100 for LTER zpk)
Ta = Total number of organism a
Equation 2: Water Volume filtered
r/t = revolutions per tow
(r/t)/(r/m) x A(m2) = V(m3) r/m = flow meter calibration
(revolutions per meter)
A(m2) = Area of net
V(m3) = volume of water filtered
Equation 3: Concentration (density)

ns2:unit.name: partPerThousand
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as parts per thousand (1:1000)
